St Christopher usually faces the entrance to the Church in his role as [[patron saint]] of travellers.</ref> Unfortunately this and other traces of [[fresco]]<ref>A fresco is where the painting is executed onto a fresh or wet plaster. With ''buon fresco'' (literally "true fresco"), paintings are executed using powder pigments ground and mixed to a paste with water. They become bound with the wall surface through the carbonation of the lime in the lime plaster. Lime putty (calcium hydroxide) sets through a process of carbonation with the water element evaporating off and atmospheric carbon dioxide being absorbed into the plaster to form calcium carbonate. As this process occurs, minute quantities of lime pass into the pigment layer and carbonate, thereby binding the pigments; http://www.buildingconservation.com/articles/medieval-wall-paintings/medieval-wall-paintings.htm.</ref> could not be saved; they were destroyed without a pictorial record of them having been made.<ref>E.G. Bowen, A History of Llanbadarn Fawr (a limited edition published under auspices of the Ysgol Cwmpadarn Centenary Celebration Joint committee/Gomer Press, Llandysul, 1979), p. 55.</ref> The committee considered an [[oak]] roof for the nave, but rejected it as too costly.<ref name="britishlistedbuildings.co.uk"/>
The tower and transepts were restored 1878–80 with a short [[spire]] similar to the original, but slated rather than oak-shingled. This work was done by Roderick Williams. The pulpit dates from this time. [[William Morris]], on behalf of the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]], wrote to the vicar in 1877<ref>The SPAB was founded by [[William Morris]], [[Philip Webb]] and others, in that year, to oppose what they saw as destructive "Restoration" of ancient buildings then occurring in [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] [[United Kingdom|Britain]]; Andrea Donovan, ''William Morris and the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings'' (Routledge, London, 2007).</ref> asking for a less severe restoration. Unfortunately much had already been destroyed.<ref name="britishlistedbuildings.co.uk"/>
The chancel finally was restored 1880–1884. The chancel glass by Stephen Belham is to Seddon’s designs.<ref>S. Belham & Co. was a company established by Stephen Belham (1827–91) in 1865 on Buckingham Palace Road in London. The firm made several stained glass windows in Wales to the design of Seddon, and then by Henry Murray (1852–1929), who may have subsequently acquired the business; http://imagingthebible.llgc.org.uk/person/274.</ref>
Further repairs and fittings were done 1935–1936 by Caroe & Passmore (primarily to the Lady Chapel), and in 1960 by George Pace (the interior porch, and light fittings).<ref>http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-9832-church-of-st-padarn-llanbadarn-fawr#.VTBJOPnF-So. For the nineteenth century restoration generally, see G. Rees, "Papers and correspondence about the restoration [by John Seddon] of Llanbadarn Fawr parish church, Cardiganshire, 1862–1870" (1960) 10(5) Journal of Historical Society of the Church in Wales 53–65; Michael Darby, ''John Pollard Seddon'' (Victoria and Albert Museum, London, 1983), p. 69.</ref> The museum and chapel of St Padarn are the most recent works, aside from the re-casting and re-hanging of the peal of bells.
===The listing of the building===
[[File:An old cross in Llanbadarn Fawr (Cer) churchyard NLW3362993.jpg|thumb|One of the crosses in Llanbadarn Fawr, in the churchyard pre-1916]]
The church has been [[Listed buildings in Wales|listed]] grade I since 21 January 1964. It was listed grade I as being the pre-eminent mediaeval church of the region, with outstanding monuments and fine later nineteenth century fittings and stained glass.<ref>Additionally, see National Library of Wales SD/F/236-239 faculties 1878, 1906, 1925 and 1936; National Library of Wales, Llanbadarn Fawr PCC records; Lambeth Palace, ICBS 06854: restoration papers; Llanbadarn Fawr drwy'r canrifoedd/ through the centuries, 1994; Martin Harrison, ''Victorian Stained Glass'' (Barrie & Jenkins, London, 1979), pp. 58–9: the glass by Belham; (1848) 7 The Ecclesiologist, pp. 250–1; Carmarthen Journal 1/8/1862, 3/1/1868, 23/2/1883, 19/9/1884, 25/5/1894; The Builder 21/8/1869, 26/7/1879, 3/7/1880, 19/4/1884; Building News 26/8/1870; The Welshman 24/1/1868, 24/11/1876, 15/3/1878, 9/6/1880; The British Architect, 1882 (plans by Seddon); J.O. ==Churchyard==
[[File:St Padarn's church, Llanbadarn Fawr - geograph.org.uk - 1452960.jpg|thumb|The north aspect of the church from the churchyard]]
The churchyard covers some two acres. Most of the [[headstone]]s in the [[churchyard]] are modern – many of them are from the nineteenth century – but the churchyard, which is now closed to new interments, contains some old monuments. The whole churchyard and church is surrounded by what was once a typical sign of an early Celtic church; an oval formation of trees.<ref>Some of the trees are certified as being over 500 years old.</ref> There are also indications which suggest the remains of an early [[pond]], probably for keeping fish for the priests and monks who once lived there. There is no visible trace of any [[monastic|conventual]] buildings (which would probably have been mostly relatively slight wooden structures, and never extensive). In the early nineteenth century Meyrick does however record the survival of what appeared to be stone monastic or church buildings.<ref>"On the north side of the church the buildings were, probably, a part of the old monastery, a pointed arch, and other circumstances in them, indicating great antiquity"; Sir [[Samuel Rush Meyrick]], ''The History and Antiquities of the county of Cardigan. Collected from the few remaining documents which have escaped the ravages of time, as well as from actual observation'' (Longmans, London, 1810).</ref>
[[File:Parish church, Llanbadarn Fawr, from the northwest - geograph.org.uk - 791247.jpg|thumb|A view from the northwest, showing part of the churchyard]]
===Lewis Pugh Evans===
[[File:Lewis Pugh Evans VC IWM HU 93411.jpg|thumb|Lewis Pugh Evans, VC]]
[[Brigadier-General]] [[Lewis Pugh Evans]], of Lovesgrove, a [[World War I]] [[Victoria Cross]] recipient and former [[churchwarden]], is buried in the [[churchyard]]. His grave is marked by a simple [[slate]] [[headstone]] giving names and dates of birth and death.<ref name=blvch>[http://www.victoriacross.org/cowalnor.htm] Burial Location VC Holders in North Wales.</ref> He was a kinsman of Major-General Lewis Pugh, who is commemorated in the south transept. Evans was awarded the VC when, as an acting [[Lieutenant Colonel]] in [[The Black Watch (Royal Highlanders)]], on 4 October 1917, near [[Zonnebeke]], [[Belgium]], he was Commanding Officer of the 1st [[Battalion]], The [[Lincolnshire Regiment]]: <blockquote>For most conspicuous bravery and leadership. Lt.-Col. Evans took his battalion in perfect order through a terrific enemy barrage, personally formed up all units, and led them to the assault. While a strong machine gun emplacement was causing casualties, and the troops were working round the flank, Lt.-Col. Evans rushed at it himself and by firing his revolver through the loophole forced the garrison to capitulate. After capturing the first objective he was severely wounded in the shoulder, but refused to be bandaged, and re-formed the troops, pointed out all future objectives, and again led his battalion forward. Again badly wounded, he nevertheless continued to command until the second objective was won, and, after consolidation, collapsed from loss of blood. As there were numerous casualties, he refused assistance, and by his own efforts ultimately reached the Dressing Station. His example of cool bravery stimulated in all ranks the highest valour and determination to win.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=30400 |supp=yes |startpage=12327 |date=23 November 1917 |accessdate=15 November 2010 }}</ref></blockquote> Evans was [[mention in despatches|mentioned in despatches]] seven times and was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]]<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=29240 |supp=yes |startpage=7280 |date=24 July 1915 |accessdate=15 November 2010 }}</ref> and [[Medal bar|Bar]], the [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)]]<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=30302 |supp=yes |startpage=9861 |date=21 September 1917 |accessdate=15 November 2010}}</ref> and the French [[Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de Guerre]]. He was made a [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] in 1919,<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=13453 |supp=yes |startpage=1826 |date=5 June 1919 |accessdate=15 November 2010 |city=e }}</ref> and a [[Order of the Bath|Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1938.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=34518 |supp=yes|startpage=3687 |date=7 June 1938 |accessdate=15 November 2010 }}. He also had the 1914 Star and Clasp, the British War Medal and the Victory Medal.</ref>
He was a [[Justice of the Peace]] on the local bench as well as [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for [[Ceredigion|Cardiganshire]]<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=34451 |startpage=6899 |date=5 November 1937 |accessdate=15 November 2010 }}</ref> and a [[Freedom of the City|Freeman]] of the [[borough]] of Aberystwyth. He was also an Officer of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem]].<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=35203 |startpage=3674 |date=27 June 1941 |accessdate=15 November 2010 }}</ref>
His VC is on display in the Lord Ashcroft Gallery at the [[Imperial War Museum]], London.<ref>http://www.victoriacross.org.uk/vvashcr3.htm.</ref>
Since 1991 a memorial plaque has been on the wall near the [[village]] [[war memorial]].
===Ancillary building===
A lean-to structure at the end of the north transept houses the heating system. There is a new western end to this building, constructed 2014, and the eastern end (which includes the entrance) can only be entered via the north door to the choir vestry.
===The churchyard gates===
The churchyard gate to the south west of the church is [[Listed buildings in Wales|listed]] grade II (26 October 2002). Given the relative size of the churchyard, the church and each of the two gates have their own [[postcode]]: the postal address of the church is Primrose Hill, Llanbadarn Fawr, Aberystwyth, Ceredigion SY23 3QZ, the postcode of the west gate is SY23 3QY.<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-27048-churchyard-gate-to-sw-of-church-of-st-pad/ "Churchyard gate to SW of Church of St Padarn, Llanbadarn Fawr" British Listed Buildings].</ref>
The [[lychgate]] to the south east is also [[Listed buildings in Wales|listed]] grade II (25 October 2002), and is located at SY23 3RA.<ref name="See 2006 p. 494-497"/> It is a stone gabled lychgate with arched entries and good iron gates. It dates from 1814.<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-27047-lychgate-to-se-of-church-of-st-padarn-lla/ "Lychgate to SE of Church of St Padarn, Llanbadarn Fawr" British Listed Buildings].</ref>
[[File:St Padarn's church, Llanbadarn Fawr - geograph.org.uk - 1452968.jpg|thumb|A photograph showing the south west gate]]
===The Church Hall===
There is a modern church hall just outside the grounds of the church, to the west of the church. This was restored in 2000.
